claim: Flublok contains 3x the hemagglutinin (HA) antigen content of standard-dose flu vaccines, which has been linked to greater immunogenicity vs standard-dose flu vaccines.
explanation: A multi-panel figure showing geometric mean microneutralization (MN) or hemagglutination inhibition (HI) antibody titers (log2 scale) against four influenza strains (A(H3N2), A(H1N1)pdm09, B/Victoria, B/Yamagata) at Day 0, 1 month, and 6 months post-vaccination. Panels are stratified by age group (18–44 vs 45–64 years) and by virus antigen preparation (egg-grown vs cell-grown). Four vaccine groups are plotted: standard-dose egg-based IIV4 (Fluzone, black), another IIV4 (blue), cell culture-derived IIV4 (green), and recombinant HA vaccine RIV4 (Flublok, orange). Statistical comparisons (p-values) between groups are annotated. Evidence: RIV4 (orange) elicits higher MN/HI titers than standard-dose egg-based IIV4 in several comparisons (e.g., A(H3N2) titers at 1 month) as indicated by significant p-values. The figure demonstrates that the recombinant HA vaccine (Flublok/RIV4) produces greater immunogenicity compared with standard-dose egg-based flu vaccines, but it does not present data on HA antigen content. Therefore, it does not support the claim regarding the 3× HA content, although it shows increased immunogenicity. Note: Image only shows immunogenicity data; no quantitative HA content information is provided. Some p-values are small and panels are densely annotated, but overall legible.

Therefore, it does not support the claim regarding the 3× HA content, although it shows increased immunogenicity.
